node.name: early embryonic cell
node.desc: A cell found in the embryo before the formation of all the gem layers is complete.

node.name: fusiform
node.desc: An elongated cell with approximately wedge-shaped ends, found in the vascular cambium, which gives rise to the elements of the axial system in the secondary vascular tissues.

node.name: spermatocyte
node.desc: A male germ cell that develops from spermatogonia.

node.name: spermatid
node.desc: A male germ cell that develops from the haploid secondary spermatocytes.

node.name: sperm
node.desc: A mature male germ cell that develops from a _______atid.

node.name: spermatogonium
node.desc: An euploid male germ cell of an early stage of spermatogenesis.

node.name: female germ cell
node.desc: _______ is a germ cell that supports female gamete production.

node.name: oocyte
node.desc: A female germ cell that has entered meiosis.

node.name: oogonial cell
node.desc: An undifferentiated germ cell that proliferates rapidly and gives rise to oocytes.

node.name: egg
node.desc: A female gamete where meiosis has progressed to metaphase II and is able to participate in fertilization.

node.name: invertebrate nurse cell
node.desc: A germline cell that contributes to the development of the oocyte by transferring cytoplasm directly to oocyte.

node.name: neuroplacodal cell
node.desc: A cell of a platelike structure, especially a thickened plate of ectoderm in the early embryo, from which a sense organ develops.

node.name: apocrine cell
node.desc: An _______ is a secretory cell characterized loss of part of the cytoplasm during the process of secretion - secretions are budded off through the plasma membrane producing membrane bound vesicles containing the secreted substance.

node.name: stem cell
node.desc: A relatively undifferentiated cell that retains the ability to divide and proliferate throughout life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into specialized cells.

node.name: single fate stem cell
node.desc: A stem cell that self-renews as well as give rise to a single mature cell type.

node.name: hematopoietic stem cell
node.desc: A stem cell from which all cells of the lymphoid and myeloid lineages develop, including blood cells and cells of the immune system. _______s lack cell markers of effector cells (lin-negative). Lin-negative is defined by lacking one or more of the following cell surface markers: CD2, CD3 epsilon, CD4, CD5 ,CD8 alpha chain, CD11b, CD14, CD19, CD20, CD56, ly6G, ter119.

node.name: erythroid progenitor cell
node.desc: A progenitor cell committed to the erythroid lineage. This cell is ter119-positive but lacks expression of other hematopoietic lineage markers (lin-negative).

node.name: germ line cell
node.desc: A cell that is within the developmental lineage of gametes and is able to pass along its genetic material to offspring.

node.name: monoblast
node.desc: A myeloid progenitor cell committed to the monocyte lineage. This cell is CD11b-positive, has basophilic cytoplasm, euchromatin, and the presence of a nucleolus.

node.name: mature eosinophil
node.desc: A fully differentiated eosinophil, a granular leukocyte with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by one or more slender threads, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and which can be stained by the dye eosin. Cells are also differentiated from other granulocytes by a small nuclear-to-cytoplasm ratio (1:3). This cell type is CD49d-positive.

node.name: neutrophilic myeloblast
node.desc: A myeloblast committed to the neutrophil lineage. This cell type is GATA-1 positive, C/EBPa-positive, AML-1-positive, c-myb-positive and has low expression of PU.1 transcription factor.

node.name: mature basophil
node.desc: A fully differentiated basophil, a granular leukocyte with an irregularly shaped, pale-staining nucleus that is partially constricted into two lobes, and with cytoplasm that contains coarse granules of variable size. Basophils contain vasoactive amines such as histamine and serotonin, which are released on appropriate stimulation.

node.name: neuronal stem cell
node.desc: Neural stem cell is characterized as an undifferentiated cell that originates from the neuroectoderm and has the capacity both to perpetually self-renew without differentiating and to generate multiple types of lineage-restricted progenitors.

node.name: multi fate stem cell
node.desc: A stem cell that can give rise to multiple lineages of cells.

node.name: common myeloid progenitor
node.desc: A progenitor cell committed to myeloid lineage, including the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages. These cells are CD34-positive, and express Gata-1, Gata2, C/EBPa, and Pu.1.

node.name: megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cell
node.desc: A progenitor cell committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages.

node.name: common lymphoid progenitor
node.desc: A oligopotent progenitor cell committed to the lymphoid lineage.

node.name: totipotent stem cell
node.desc: A stem cell from which all cells of the body can form.

node.name: non-terminally differentiated cell
node.desc: A precursor cell with a limited number of potential fates.

node.name: myoblast
node.desc: A precursor cell of the myogenic lineage that develops from the mesoderm. They undergo proliferation, migrate to their various sites, and then differentiate into the appropriate form of myocytes.

node.name: fibroblast
node.desc: A connective tissue cell which secretes an extracellular matrix rich in collagen and other macromolecules. Flattened and irregular in outline with branching processes; appear fusiform or spindle-shaped.

node.name: chondroblast
node.desc: An immature cartilage-producing cell found in growing cartilage.

node.name: ameloblast
node.desc: A cylindrical epithelial cell in the innermost layer of the enamel organ

node.name: odontoblast
node.desc: One of the cells forming the outer surface of dental pulp that produces tooth dentin.

node.name: cementoblast
node.desc: A cell of ectomesenchymal origin that aids in the formation the cementum layer on the roots of teeth.

node.name: osteoblast
node.desc: A bone-forming cell which secretes an extracellular matrix. Hydroxyapatite crystals are then deposited into the matrix to form bone.

node.name: cell by histology
node.desc: A classification of cells by their microscopic appearance.

node.name: ciliated cell
node.desc: A cell that has a filiform extrusion of the cell surface.

node.name: ependymal cell
node.desc: A neurectoderm derived cell that lines the neural lumen.

node.name: epithelial cell
node.desc: A cell that is usually found in a two-dimensional sheet with a free surface. The cell has a cytoskeleton that allows for tight cell to cell contact and for cell polarity where apical part is directed towards the lumen and the basal part to the basal lamina.

node.name: ciliated epithelial cell
node.desc: An epithelial cell that has a cillia.

node.name: blood vessel endothelial cell
node.desc: An endothelial cell that lines the vasculature.

node.name: epithem cell
node.desc: A cell that constitutes the mesophyll of a hydathode and is located between the xylem endings and the epidermis. Proposed to be involved in the retrieval of solutes from the xylem sap.

node.name: mesothelial cell
node.desc: A flattened epithelial cell of mesenchymal origin that lines the serous cavity.

node.name: circulating cell
node.desc: A cell which moves among different tissues of the body, via blood, lymph, or other medium.

node.name: blood cell
node.desc: A cell found predominately in the blood.

node.name: epithelial cell of pancreas
node.desc: An epithelial cell of the pancreas.

node.name: T cell
node.desc: A type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of a _______ receptor complex.

node.name: Kupffer cell
node.desc: A tissue-resident macrophage of the reticuloendothelial system found on the luminal surface of the hepatic sinusoids involved in erythrocyte clearance. Markers include F4/80+, CD11b-low, CD68-positive, sialoadhesin-positive, CD163/SRCR-positive.

node.name: osteoclast
node.desc: A specialized phagocytic cell associated with the absorption and removal of the mineralized matrix of bone tissue, which typically differentiates from monocytes. This cell has the following markers: tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase type 5-positive, PU.1-positive, c-fos-positive, nuclear factor NF-kappa-B p100 subunit-positive, tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 11A-positive and macrophage colony-stimulating factor 1 receptor-positive.

node.name: granulocyte
node.desc: A leukocyte with abundant granules in the cytoplasm.

node.name: mature neutrophil
node.desc: A fully differentiated neutrophil, a granular leukocyte having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes. They are produced in bone marrow at a rate of 5e10-10e10/ day and have a half-life of 6-8 hours. Neutrophils are CD15-positive, CD16-positive, CD32-positive, CD43-positive, CD181-positive, and CD182-positive ."

node.name: mast cell
node.desc: A cell that is found in almost all tissues containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation. Progenitors leave bone marrow and mature in connective and mucosal tissue. Mature _______s are found in all tissues, except the bloodstream. Their phenotype is CD117-high, CD123-negative, CD193-positive, CD200R3-positive, and FceRI-high. Stem-cell factor (KIT-ligand; SCF) is the main controlling signal of their survival and development.

node.name: sensory epithelial cell
node.desc: A specialized epithelial cell involved in sensory perception. Restricted to special sense organs of the olfactory, gustatory, and vestibulocochlear receptor systems; contain sensory cells surrounded by supportive, non-receptive cells.

node.name: interneuron
node.desc: Most generally any neuron which is not motor or sensory. _______s may also refer to neurons whose axons remain within a particular brain region as contrasted with projection neurons which have axons projecting to other brain regions.

node.name: motor neuron
node.desc: An efferent neuron that passes from the central nervous system or a ganglion toward or to a muscle and conducts an impulse that causes movement.

node.name: sensory neuron
node.desc: Any neuron having a sensory function; an afferent neuron conveying sensory impulses.

node.name: bipolar neuron
node.desc: A type of interneuron that has two neurites, usually an axon and a dendrite, extending from opposite poles of an ovoid cell body.

node.name: multipolar neuron
node.desc: Neuron with an axon and two or more dendrites.

node.name: pseudounipolar neuron
node.desc: Neuron with two neurites that are fused grossly when they protrude from the soma and bifurcate a short distance from the soma.

node.name: unipolar neuron
node.desc: Neuron with an axon and no dendrites.

node.name: autonomic neuron
node.desc: A neruon whose cell body is within an autonomic ganglion.

node.name: cholinergic neuron
node.desc: A neuron that uses acetylcholine as a vesicular neurotransmitter.

node.name: peripheral neuron
node.desc: A neuron that is part of nerve found outside the central nervous system.

node.name: mononuclear phagocyte
node.desc: A vertebrate phagocyte with a single nucleus.

node.name: endothelial cell
node.desc: An _______ comprises the outermost layer or lining of anatomical structures and can be squamous or cuboidal. In mammals, _______ has vimentin filaments and is derived from the mesoderm.

node.name: pioneer neuron
node.desc: _______s establish a pathway in the developing central nervous system and then undergo programmed cell death once the adult axons, which follow them, have made connections with the target site. Thus, they are a transient cell type involved in axon guidance.

node.name: Purkinje cell
node.desc: The output neuron of the cerebellar cortex.

node.name: glial cell
node.desc: A non-neuronal cell of the nervous system. They not only provide physical support, but also respond to injury, regulate the ionic and chemical composition of the extracellular milieu. Guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons.

node.name: macroglial cell
node.desc: A neuroglial cell of ectodermal origin, i.e., the astrocytes and oligodendrocytes considered together.

node.name: astrocyte
node.desc: A class of large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord. _______s (from 'star' cells) are irregularly shaped with many long processes, including those with 'end feet' which form the glial (limiting) membrane and directly and indirectly contribute to the blood-brain barrier. They regulate the extracellular ionic and chemical environment, and 'reactive _______s' (along with microglia) respond to injury.

node.name: oligodendrocyte
node.desc: A class of large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system. Form the insulating myelin sheath of axons in the central nervous system.

node.name: microglial cell
node.desc: A central nervous system macrophage found in the parenchyma of the central nervous system. Marker include CD11b-positive, F4/80-positive, and CD68-positive.

node.name: corneal endothelial cell
node.desc: Cell of the single layer of large flattened cells covering the surface of the cornea.

node.name: neurectodermal cell
node.desc: Ectoderm destined to be nervous tissue.

node.name: mesenchymal cell
node.desc: A connective tissue cell that normally gives rise to other cells that are organized as three-dimensional masses. This cell type is CD73-positive, CD90-positive, CD105-positive, CD45-negative, CD34-negative, and MHCII-negative. They may further differentiate into osteoblasts, adipocytes, myocytes, neurons, or chondroblasts in vitro. Originally described as residing in the bone marrow, this cell type is now known to reside in many, if not all, adult organs.

node.name: fibrocyte
node.desc: An inactive fibroblast; cytoplasm is sparse, endoplasmic reticulum is scanty with flattened nucleus. Term used by some histologists; when fibroblasts become relatively inactive in fiber formation. However, this cell has the potential for fibrogenesis in quiescent connective tissue of the adult, as well as during development, other histologists prefer to use the term fibroblast in all circumstances. These cells represent ~0.5% of peripheral blood leukocytes.

node.name: fat cell
node.desc: A fat-storing cell found mostly in the abdominal cavity and subcutaneous tissue of mammals. Fat is usually stored in the form of triglycerides.

node.name: osteocyte
node.desc: A mature osteoblast that has become embedded in the bone matrix. They occupy a small cavity, called lacuna, in the matrix and are connected to adjacent _______s via protoplasmic projections called canaliculi.

node.name: chondrocyte
node.desc: Polymorphic cell that form cartilage.

node.name: cementocyte
node.desc: An osteocytelike cell with numerous processes, trapped in a lacuna in the cement of the tooth.

node.name: hyalocyte
node.desc: A cell occurring in the peripheral part of the vitreous body of the eye that may be responsible for production of hyaluronic acid and collagen.

node.name: cell by function
node.desc: A classification of cells by their primary end goal or behavior.

node.name: professional antigen presenting cell
node.desc: A cell capable of processing and presenting lipid and protein antigens to T cells in order to initiate an immune response.

node.name: pigment cell
node.desc: A _______ is a cell that contains pigment granules.

node.name: melanocyte
node.desc: A pigment cell derived from the neural crest. Contains melanin-filled pigment granules, which gives a brown to black appearance.

node.name: glandular epithelial cell
node.desc: A specialized epithelial cell that is capable of synthesizing and secreting certain biomolecules.

node.name: secretory cell
node.desc: A cell that specializes in controlled release of one or more substances.

node.name: exocrine cell
node.desc: A cell of an exocrine gland, i.e. a gland that discharges its secretion via a duct.

node.name: GAG secreting cell
node.desc: A cell that secretes glycosaminoglycans.

node.name: peptic cell
node.desc: A cell that is usually basal in position, cuboidal with round nucleus, short microvilli, secretes pepsinogen.

node.name: antibody secreting cell
node.desc: OBSOLETE: A cell of the lymphoid series that can react with antigen to produce specific cell products called antibodies. Various cell subpopulations, often B cells, can be defined, based on the different classes of immunoglobulins that they synthesize.

node.name: surfactant secreting cell
node.desc: A cell that specializes in secretion of surfactant in the alveoli of the lung.

node.name: Clara cell
node.desc: Epithelial progenitor cell of the lung. _______s are dome-shaped with short microvilli but no cilia. They function to protect the bronchiolar epithelium. _______s also multiply and differentiate into ciliated cells to regenerate the bronchiolar epithelium.

node.name: goblet cell
node.desc: A cell of the epithelial lining that produce and secrete mucins.

node.name: parietal cell
node.desc: A large, oval stomach epithelial cell with a central nucleus; source of gastric acid. Secretes HCl.

node.name: endocrine cell
node.desc: A cell of an endocrine gland, ductless glands that secrete substances which are released directly into the circulation and which influence metabolism and other body functions.

node.name: enteroendocrine cell
node.desc: An endocrine cell that is located in the epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract or in the pancreas.

node.name: neuroendocrine cell
node.desc: An endocrine cell that has the specialized function to produce and secrete hormones in response to neuronal signals.

node.name: chromaffin cell
node.desc: A cell that stores epinephrine secretory vesicles. During times of stress, the nervous system signals the vesicles to secrete their hormonal content. Their name derives from their ability to stain a brownish color with chromic salts. Characteristically, they are located in the adrenal medulla and paraganglia of the sympathetic nervous system.

node.name: type B pancreatic cell
node.desc: A cell that secretes insulin and is located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans.

node.name: glucagon secreting cell
node.desc: A cell that secretes glucagon.

node.name: pancreatic A cell
node.desc: A type of enteocrine cell found in the periphery of the islets of Langerhans that secretes glucagon.

node.name: pancreatic D cell
node.desc: A D cell located in the pancreas. Peripherally placed within the islets like type A cells; contains somatostatin.

node.name: luteal cell
node.desc: A progesterone secreting cell in the corpus luteum. The large _______s develop from the granulosa cells. The small _______s develop from the theca cells.

node.name: Leydig cell
node.desc: A _______ is a testosterone-secreting cell in the interstitial area, between the seminiferous tubules, in the testis.

node.name: metabolising cell
node.desc: A cell whose primary function is intermediary metabolism.

node.name: hepatocyte
node.desc: The main structural component of the liver. They are specialized epithelial cells that are organized into interconnected plates called lobules. Majority of cell population of liver, polygonal in shape, arranged in plates or trabeculae between sinusoids; may have single nucleus or binucleated.

node.name: contractile cell
node.desc: A cell whose primary function is to shorten.

node.name: myoepithelial cell
node.desc: Contractile cells resembling smooth muscle cells that are present in glands, notably the mammary gland, and aid in secretion. This cell has long weaving dendritic processes containing myofilament.

node.name: myofibroblast cell
node.desc: An animal cell that has characteristics of both a fibroblast cell and a smooth muscle cell.

node.name: muscle cell
node.desc: A mature contractile cell, commonly known as a myocyte. This cell has as part of its cytoplasm myofibrils organized in various patterns.

node.name: skeletal muscle cell
node.desc: A somatic cell located in skeletal muscle.

node.name: slow muscle cell
node.desc: A muscle cell that develops tension more slowly than a fast-twitch fiber.

node.name: fast muscle cell
node.desc: A muscle cell that can develop high tension rapidly. It is usually innervated by a single alpha neuron .

node.name: smooth muscle cell
node.desc: A non-striated, elongated, spindle-shaped cell found lining the digestive tract, uterus, and blood vessels. They develop from specialized myoblasts (smooth muscle myoblast).

node.name: cardiac muscle cell (sensu Arthopoda)
node.desc: A striated muscle cell found in the heart. They develop from cardiac myoblasts.

node.name: pain receptor cell
node.desc: The peripheral receptor for pain. Includes receptors which are sensitive to painful mechanical stimuli, extreme heat or cold, and chemical stimuli. All mammalian nociceptors are free nerve endings.

node.name: mechanoreceptor cell
node.desc: A cell specialized to transduce mechanical stimuli and relay that information centrally in the nervous system.

node.name: auditory hair cell
node.desc: A mechanoreceptor cell located in the inner ear that is sensitive to auditory stimuli. The accessory sensory structures are arranged so that appropriate stimuli cause movement of the hair-like projections (stereocilia and kinocilia) which relay the information centrally in the nervous system.

node.name: thermoreceptor cell
node.desc: A cellular receptor which mediates the sense of temperature. _______s in vertebrates are mostly located under the skin. In mammals there are separate types of thermoreceptors for cold and for warmth and pain receptor cells which detect cold or heat extreme enough to cause pain.

node.name: chemoreceptor cell
node.desc: A cell specialized to detect chemical substances and relay that information centrally in the nervous system. Chemoreceptors may monitor external stimuli, as in taste and olfaction, or internal stimuli, such as the concentrations of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood.

node.name: taste receptor cell
node.desc: A cell type found in the spherical or ovoid clusters of receptor cells found mainly in the epithelium of the tongue and constituting the end organs of the sense of taste.

node.name: photoreceptor cell
node.desc: A cell specialized to detect and transduce light.

node.name: electrically active cell
node.desc: A cell whose function is determined by the generation or the reception of an electric signal.

node.name: absorptive cell
node.desc: A cell that takes up and metabolizes substances.

node.name: lining cell
node.desc: A cell within an epithelial cell sheet whose main function is to act as an internal or external covering for a tissue or an organism.

node.name: synovial cell
node.desc: A meso-epithelial cell that lies between the cartilaginous fibers in the synovial membrane of a joint and produces hyaluronic acid.

node.name: barrier cell
node.desc: A cell whose primary function is to prevent the transport of stuff across compartments.

node.name: Sertoli cell
node.desc: A supporting cell projecting inward from the basement membrane of seminiferous tubules. They surround and nourish the developing male germ cells and secrete androgen binding protein. Their tight junctions with the spermatogonia and spermatocytes provide a blood-testis barrier.

node.name: myelinating Schwann cell
node.desc: A neuroglial cell of the peripheral nervous system which forms the insulating myelin sheaths of peripheral axons.

node.name: motile cell
node.desc: A cell that moves by its own activities.

node.name: ectodermal cell
node.desc: A cell of the outer of the three germ layers of the embryo.

node.name: mesodermal cell
node.desc: A cell of the middle germ layer of the embryo.

node.name: endodermal cell
node.desc: A cell of the inner of the three germ layers of the embryo.

node.name: cell by nuclear number
node.desc: A classification of cells by the number of their nuclei.

node.name: anucleate cell
node.desc: A cell that lacks a nucleus.

node.name: single nucleate cell
node.desc: A cell with a single nucleus.

node.name: multinucleate cell
node.desc: A cell with more than one nucleus.

node.name: erythrocyte
node.desc: A red blood cell. In mammals, mature _______s are biconcave disks containing hemoglobin whose function is to transport oxygen.

node.name: platelet
node.desc: A non-nucleated disk-shaped cell formed by extrusion from megakaryocytes, found in the blood of all mammals, and mainly involved in blood coagulation.

node.name: phagocyte
node.desc: Any cell capable of ingesting particulate matter via phagocytosis.

node.name: macrophage
node.desc: A mononuclear phagocyte present in variety of tissues, typically differentiated from monocytes, capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells.

node.name: B cell
node.desc: A lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of _______ mediated immunity.

node.name: Merkel cell
node.desc: A modified epidermal cell located in the stratum basale. They are found mostly in areas where sensory perception is acute. _______s are closely associated with an expanded terminal bulb of an afferent myelinated nerve fiber.

node.name: glial cell (sensu Vertebrata)
node.desc: A non-neuronal cell of the nervous system. They not only provide physical support, but also respond to injury, regulate the ionic and chemical composition of the extracellular milieu. Form the myelin insulation of nervous pathways, guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons. Neuroglia have high-affinity transmitter uptake systems, voltage-dependent and transmitter-gated ion channels, and can release transmitters, but their role in signaling (as in many other functions) is unclear.

node.name: transitional epithelial cell
node.desc: A cell characteristically found lining hollow organs that are subject to great mechanical change due to contraction and distention; originally thought to represent a transition between stratified squamous and columnar epithelium.

node.name: passage cell
node.desc: Cell in exodermis or endodermis that remains thin walled when the associated cells develop thick secondary walls. Has casparian strip in endodermis.

node.name: microsporocyte
node.desc: A diploid (2n) cell that undergoes meiosis and forms four haploid (1n) microspores; also called microspore mother cell and, in seed plants, pollen mother cell.

node.name: megaspore
node.desc: A haploid (1n) spore developing into a female gametophyte in heterosporous plants.

node.name: microspore
node.desc: A haploid (1n) spore developing into a male gametophyte in heterosporous plants; the uninucleate pollen grain in seed plants.

node.name: egg cell
node.desc: Obsolete. Use PO:0020094 from Plant Ontology instead. The female gamete of plants.

node.name: fiber tracheid
node.desc: A fiber like tracheid in the secondary xylem; commonly thick walled, with pointed ends and bordered pits that have lenticular to slit like apertures.

node.name: aggregate cell
node.desc: Differentiating cell composing the aggregate that has acquired adhesive properties.

node.name: mucilage cell
node.desc: Cell containing mucilages or gums or similar carbohydrate material characterized by the property of swelling in water.

node.name: guard mother cell
node.desc: An epidermal cell that divides to produce the guard cells.

node.name: vegetative cell (sensu Mycetozoa)
node.desc: Unicellular haploid myxamoebae that feeds on bacteria and divides by binary fission.

node.name: phloem initial
node.desc: A cambial cell on the phloem side of the cambial zone that is the source of one or more cells arising by periclinal divisions and differentiating into phloem elements with or without additional divisions in various planes.

node.name: anterior like cell
node.desc: Cell that has properties of anterior cells (for e.g., accumulate vital dyes in autophagic vesicles) but that is are scattered throughout the rear of the slug. Some but not all these cells express the ecmA gene and/or the ecmB gene. ALCs maintain an amoeboid appearance during culmination. ALCs that express the ecmO promoter have been called pstO/ALC.

node.name: meristemoid
node.desc: A cell constituting an active locus of meristematic activity in a tissue composed of somewhat older, differentiating cells.

node.name: prespore cell
node.desc: Cell that is undergoing differentiation to become a spore.

node.name: sieve element
node.desc: Obsolete. Consult Plant Ontology instead. The cell in the phloem tissue concerned with mainly longitudinal conduction of food materials. Classified into sieve cell and sieve tube member.

node.name: subsidiary cell
node.desc: An epidermal cell associated with a stoma and at least morphologically distinguishable from the epidermal cells composing the groundmass of the tissue.

node.name: prestalk A cell
node.desc: Cell expressing the ecmA marker from a promoter region that is proximal to the ATG (ecmAO promoter). They are located at the anterior-most region of the slug. During culmination pstA cells differentiate into pstAB cells.

node.name: cambial initial
node.desc: OBSOLETE, use term from Plant Ontology. A cell localized in the vascular cambium or phellogen. Its periclinal division can contribute cells either to the outside or to the inside of the axis; in vascular cambium, classified into fusiform initials (source of axial cells of xylem and phloem) and ray initials (source of the ray cells).

node.name: prestalk AB cell
node.desc: Cell that expresses both ecmA and ecmB either simultaneously or sequentially. During culmination pstA differentiate into pstAB cells.

node.name: prestalk B cell
node.desc: Cell expressing ecmB but not ecmA. Most pstB cells are located at the very rear of the slug (rearguard region). These cells form part of the basal disc of the fruiting body. If a migratory slug is formed, these cells are left behind.

node.name: sclerenchyma cell
node.desc: Cell variable in form and size, being more or less thick, often lignified, secondary walls. Belongs to the category of subcells and may or may not be devoid of protoplast at maturity.

node.name: prestalk I cell
node.desc: Initial population of prestalk cells that activate the ecmA promoter at the mound stage and that presumably further differentiate into pstA and pstO cells.

node.name: central cell
node.desc: A cell containing the two polar nuclei which, after double fertilization, will develop into the endosperm.

node.name: prestalk 0 cell
node.desc: Cell that express ecmA at a very low level. Located at the posterior half of the prestalk zone. Expresses ecmA from the distal region of its promoter (ecmO).

node.name: generative cell
node.desc: The cell that will give rise to the generative nuclei which will participate in fertilization.

node.name: pstAB/ALC
node.desc: Anterior-like cell expressing both ecmA and ecmB.

node.name: trichome
node.desc: An outgrowth from the epidermis. _______s vary in size and complexity and include hairs, scales, and other structures and may be glandular. In Arabidopsis, patterning of _______ development is not random but does not appear to be lineage-based like stomata.

node.name: pstO/ALC
node.desc: Anterior-like cell that expresses the ecmO promoter and that can move to the position normally occupied by the pstO cells.

node.name: companion cell
node.desc: A specialized parenchyma cell associated with a sieve-tube member in angiosperm phloem and arising from the same mother cell as the sieve-tube member.

node.name: stalk cell
node.desc: Vacuolated cell located at the center of the stalk tube that has a cell wall composed of cellulose and that die upon terminal differentiation. _______s provide structural support for the fruiting body.

node.name: hyphal cell
node.desc: A cell of a filament of a fungal mycelium.

node.name: synergid
node.desc: A cell in the micropylar end of the embryo sac associated with the egg in the egg apparatus of angiosperms. Plays a vital role in fertilization.

node.name: chemotactic amoeboid cell (sensu Mycetozoa)
node.desc: Starved cell that secretes and responds to chemoattractants (cAMP).

node.name: xylem fiber cell
node.desc: A fiber of the xylem tissue, Two types are recognized in the secondary xylem: fiber tracheids and libriform fibers.

node.name: spore (sensu Mycetozoa)
node.desc: Dormant cell protected by a tri-layer spore coat. The spore has an elliptical shape and is approximately 6-9 microns by 3 microns.

node.name: guard cell
node.desc: One of a pair of cells flanking the stomatal pore and causing the opening and closing of the pore by changes in turgor.

node.name: structural cell
node.desc: A cell whose primary function is to provide structural support, to provide strength and physical integrity to the organism.

node.name: sieve cell
node.desc: Obsolete. Consult Plant Ontology instead. A type of sieve element that has relatively undifferentiated sieve areas (with narrow pores), rather uniform in structure on all walls; that is, there are no sieve plates. Typical of gymnosperms and lower vascular plants.

node.name: somatotropin secreting cell
node.desc: A peptide hormone secreting cell that produces growth hormone, somatotropin.

node.name: vegetative cell
node.desc: Cell type formed after the first mitotic division of the microgametophye, The nucleus of this cell migrates to the tip of the pollen tube after germination and disintegrates when the pollen tube penetrates the nucellus.

node.name: socket cell
node.desc: A cell that surrounds a trichome and provides support for the trichome.

node.name: xylem element
node.desc: Obsolete. Use PO:0000273 from Plant Ontology instead. A cell composing the xylem.

node.name: trichoblast
node.desc: Commonly used for a cell in root epidermis that gives rise to a root hair. The daughter cell produced by the asymmetric division of a root epidermal cell that gives rise to a root hair.

node.name: gamete
node.desc: A mature sexual reproductive cell having a single set of unpaired chromosomes.

node.name: IgM B cell
node.desc: OBSOLETE (was not defined before being made obsolete).

node.name: tracheal epithelial cell
node.desc: An epithelial cell found in the trachea.

node.name: keratinocyte
node.desc: An epidermal cell which synthesizes keratin and undergoes a characteristic change as it moves upward from the basal layers of the epidermis to the cornified (horny) layer of the skin. Successive stages of differentiation of the _______s forming the epidermal layers are basal cell, spinous or prickle cell, and the granular cell.

node.name: serous secreting cell
node.desc: Columnar glandular cell with irregular nucleus, copious granular endoplasmic reticulum and supranuclear granules. Secretes a watery fluid containing proteins known as serous fluid.

node.name: tears secreting cell
node.desc: A cell secreting tears, the fluid secreted by the lacrimal glands. This fluid moistens the conjunctiva and cornea.

node.name: ray initial
node.desc: A meristemic ray cell in the vascular cambium that gives rise to ray cells of the secondary xylem and secondary phloem.

node.name: sebum secreting cell
node.desc: A cell secreting sebun, an oily substance secreted by sebaceous glands, composed of keratin, fat, and cellular debris.

node.name: sweat secreting cell
node.desc: A cell secreting sweat, the fluid excreted by the sweat glands of mammals. It consists of water containing sodium chloride, phosphate, urea, ammonia, and other waste products.

node.name: megasporocyte
node.desc: A diploid (2n) cell that undergoes meiosis and produces four haploid (1n) megaspores; also called megaspore mother cell.

node.name: pneumocyte
node.desc: An epithelial cell that lines the peripheral gas exchange region of the lungs of air-breathing vertebrates.

node.name: stuff accumulating cell
node.desc: A cell that is specialised to accumulate a particular substance(s).

node.name: collenchymal cell
node.desc: An elongated living cell with unevenly thickened nonlignified primary walls.

node.name: tracheid
node.desc: A tracheary element of the xylem that has no perforations, as contrasted with a vessel member. May occur in primary and in secondary xylem. May have any kind of secondary wall thickening found in tracheary elements.

node.name: atrichoblast
node.desc: A cell formed after asymmetric division of root epidermal cell that does not give rise to a root hair.

node.name: neural crest cell
node.desc: A cell of the strip of specialized ectoderm flanking each side of the embryonal neural plate, which after the closure of the neural tube, forms a column of isolated cells along the dorsal aspect of the neural tube. Most of the cranial and all of the spinal sensory ganglion cells arise by differentiation of _______s.

node.name: mesenchyme condensation cell
node.desc: A mesenchymal cell in embryonic development found in a contracting mass and that gives rise to osteoprogenitors.

node.name: adrenal medulla chromaffin cell
node.desc: A cell found within the adrenal medulla that secrete biogenic amine hormones upon stimulation.

node.name: neuroblast (sensu Vertebrata)
node.desc: An embryonic cell that develops into a nerve cell or neuron.

node.name: glioblast (sensu Vertebrata)
node.desc: An early neural cell developing from the early ependymal cell of the neural tube.

node.name: pigment cell (sensu Vertebrata)
node.desc: Any animal cell containing pigment granules.

node.name: visual pigment cell (sensu Vertebrata)
node.desc: A pigment cell that is capable of detecting light stimulus that is involved in visual perception.

node.name: dental papilla cell
node.desc: A small mass of condensed mesenchyme in the enamel organ; it differentiates into the dentin and dental pulp.

node.name: hair follicle dermal papilla cell
node.desc: A specialized mesenchymal cell that resides in the dermal papilla located at the bottom of hair follicles. This cell plays a pivotal roles in hair formation, growth, and cycling.

node.name: scleral cell
node.desc: A cell of the sclera of the eye.

node.name: choroidal cell of the eye
node.desc: A cell of the choroid of the eye.

node.name: trophoblast cell
node.desc: A cell lining the outside of the blastocyst. After binding to the endometrium, _______s develop into two distinct layers, an inner layer of mononuclear cyto_______s and an outer layer of continuous multinuclear cytoplasm, the syncytio_______s, which form the early fetal-maternal interface.

node.name: epiblast cell
node.desc: A cell of the outer layer of a blastula that gives rise to the ectoderm after gastrulation.

node.name: blastoderm cell
node.desc: An undifferentiated cell produced by early cleavages of the fertilized egg (zygote).
